newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch closing share market report.
newsitem.headline: Dutch closing share market report.

text.p: Dutch shares closed higher on Wednesday with most price gains made in the first few minutes as trading fizzled out in the absence of new impetus.
The AEX index ended at 554.16 points, up 3.18 points on the previous close but not enough to erase Tuesday's losses.
"There's not a lot going on but we had a good move and sustained it the whole way," said one dealer.
Market leader Royal Dutch added 3.80 to 256.60 guilders in the wake of the surge in oil prices after U.S. attacks on Iraqi military targets in the last two days.
Consumer products giant Unilever gained 6.40 to 248.90.
The strong move by Unilever, the index's second largest constituent, was attributed to a delayed reaction to a Monday newspaper report it planned to review underperforming assets.
"As the price moves up, other people react to the news. They don't want to miss the boat," said another dealer.
Brewer Heineken bounced back from recent weakness to end 2.20 guilders higher at 370.60, but smaller rival Grolsch shed 0.50 to 69.50 after an as-expected 11 pct half-year profit rise.
Packaging group Van Leer lost 0.70 to 32.20 after going ex a final 0.25 guilder dividend, but financial stocks including ABN AMRO and Aegon gained in line with the bond market.
One trader said he expected Royal Dutch shares to ease tomorrow as he believed the response to the Iraqi conflict to date was overdone.
Another expected flat trading on Thursday as market players, nervous about the possibility of another U.S. interest rate hike, awaited U.S. August payrolls data on Friday.
But chartists said the index was tracing out a reverse head and shoulders pattern which could see it breaking up through resistance at 570 toward targets at 590, 600 and 610 points.
"Technically, you should be very bullish," said one.
